awd_titl_txt: Battery Cathodes with Optimized Interfacial Stability Through the Tailored Design of Core-Shell Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
Rechargeable lithium ion batteries help to enable sustainable energy systems by storing electricity generated by intermittent renewable resources such as wind and solar energy, or by powering zero-emission electric vehicles charged by electricity from renewable resources.  However, the performance of lithium ion batteries degrades over repeated recharging cycles because of unwanted reactions that occur at the boundary between the battery electrode and the electrolyte. This project will develop new electrode materials for preventing these unwanted reactions.  The key innovation is to coat nanoscale crystals of the lithium-based energy storage material with a very thin layer of other materials that are tailored to block these undesired reactions but maintain performance.  The coating is uniformly applied to all the nanocrystals, and so that when the crystals are formed into an electrode, there are no gaps in the coating.  The educational activities associated with this project involve mentoring of undergraduate students for summer research, and outreach to high school students in the Chicago area.  The goals of the outreach activities are to communicate the value of energy storage technology in modern society to diverse groups of high school students in the Chicago area, and to encourage these students to pursue education and careers in STEM fields.  

This overall goal of this research is to improve the ability of lithium ion battery cathodes to withstand extreme cycling environments by maximizing interfacial stability without sacrificing energy storage capacity, power delivery, and recharging time.  Cathode-electrolyte instabilities have been linked to the presence of electroactive transition metals at the surface of the electrode.  These instabilities result in irreversible transformations at these interfaces, with formation of insulating layers that impede transport as well as material loss due to corrosion. Core-shell architectures can address interfacial instability.  The shell will be rich in inactive aluminum ions that minimize irreversible transformations at the interface, and the core will be composed of active transition metal oxides (Mn, Ni, Co) with high charge storage capacity. Furthermore, the shell will be thin to reduce storage capacity loss, and conformal to passivate all interfaces.  To gain a fundamental understanding of the ability these core-shell cathode materials to maintain electrode stability, the research plan has three objectives. The first objective is to fabricate core-epitaxial shell nanocrystals for high voltage, high energy battery cathodes.  The second objective is to design and evaluate core-shell architectures at the secondary particle level, and the third objective is to construct of full lithium ion cells and characterize of their interfacial mechanisms of operation.  As part of this research, synthesis and fabrication tools will be developed to effectively coat all interfaces with tailored materials and create integrated cathode architectures where appropriate levels of electron and ion transport are imparted.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Funded by the Electrochemical Systems program of the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems, this research program advanced the ability of Li-ion battery cathodes to withstand extreme cycling environments, by maximizing interfacial stability without detriment to storage and rate capability. The team at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) engineered core-shell architectures where the shell is rich in an inactive ion that minimizes deleterious interactions, and the core is an active transition metal oxide with high capacity of storage of charge. The team leveraged both traditional powder processing strategies and those emerging from the explosion of nanotechnology in the dawn of the 21st century.

The main focus of the activities was on overcoming challenges to the synthesis of materials displaying thin shells grown conformally at each primary particle, to fully passivate interfaces that are buried in the final electrode architecture. A suite of methods of sequential colloidal growth of complex oxides and overlayers was developed and demonstrated for a variety of cathode candidates. Furthermore, post-synthetic annealing was used to tailor the specific chemistry of the shell. The result was a library of nanocrystals composed of cores made of high energy cathodes, from simple layered oxides to spinels, with a shell enriched in aluminum, deposited conformally through a one-pot colloidal synthetic method. The presence of an electrochemically inactive element like aluminum at the surface served to suppressed deleterious side reactions that impact device durability. Indeed, the finely tailored nanostructures enhanced their capacity retentions compared to the bare counterparts, while minimizing losses of the original properties, especially in extreme conditions, such as high temperature.

This grant received two supplements from the INTERN program in CBET. They funded the internship at the Cell Analysis, Manufacturing and Prototyping (CAMP) facility at Argonne National Laboratory by a member of the team at UIC. The goal was to evaluate the new generation of core-shell materials made by UIC in full Li-ion batteries built at CAMP, using graphite anodes validated to meet realistic benchmarks of industry, so that the comparison with leading cathode materials could be established. The cycling performance of the cells was evaluated under high temperature and high rate of testing.

The grant supported two graduate students at UIC, both of whom graduated and found jobs at Argonne National Laboratory, thanks to connections made by our research program. Two undergraduate students conducted research at UIC that was motivated by the goals of this grant. A total of nine publications were funded by this grant, as well as several presentations in international conferences. The Principal Investigator used the connection to the topics of high technological relevance in green energy to conduct outreach activities in elementary schools, including during the lockdowns of the COVID-19 pandemic, and develop a summer workshop on the frontiers of electrochemical research.


Last Modified: 12/10/2022
Modified by: Jordi Cabana

The team at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) engineered core-shell  architectures where the shell is rich in an inactive ion that minimizes  deleterious interactions, and the core is an active  transition metal oxide with high capacity of storage of charge. The team leveraged both traditional powder processing strategies and those emerging from the explosion of nanotechnology in the dawn of  the 21st century.

The main focus of the activities was on overcoming challenges to the synthesis of materials displaying thin shells grown conformally at each  primary particle, to fully passivate interfaces that are buried in the  final electrode architecture. A suite of  methods of sequential colloidal growth of complex oxides and overlayers was developed and demonstrated for a variety of cathode candidates. Furthermore, post-synthetic  annealing was used to tailor the  specific chemistry of the shell. The result was a library of nanocrystals composed of cores made of high energy cathodes, from simple layered oxides to spinels, with a shell enriched in aluminum, deposited  conformally through a one-pot colloidal synthetic method. The presence of an electrochemically inactive element like aluminum at the surface served to suppressed deleterious side reactions that impact device durability. Indeed, the finely  tailored nanostructures enhanced their capacity retentions compared to  the bare counterparts, while minimizing losses of the original  properties, especially in extreme conditions, such as high temperature.

This grant received two supplements from the INTERN program in CBET. They funded the internship at the Cell Analysis, Manufacturing and Prototyping (CAMP) facility at Argonne National Laboratory by a member of the team at UIC. The grant supported two graduate students at UIC, both of whom graduated and found jobs at Argonne National Laboratory, thanks to connections made by our research program.
